content.description: Overhanging dihedral in a shallow corner. Lots of stemming, with a couple of thank-god face holds thrown in. Would certainly be four stars if it were a little longer.
content.location: On the left side of the wall.  Look for the super-steep corner system.

content.description:
This is the wildly frustrating, yet rewarding dihedral left of Loser's Club. Climb up to a rightward traverse on a ramp leading towards two or three moves shared with Loser's Club. After clipping the fourth bolt, decipher a frustratingly technical traverse left under the arete. The crux sequence took me an inordinate amount of time to figure out, and would be a very impressive onsight! Continue up the technical dihedral with a second crux just before the fifth bolt that requires a tenuous deadpoint or a one armed dyno with your bolt down below your feet. Biffing the throw would result in a WILD fall out into space (get your cameras ready!)

*Don't clip any bolts on Loser's Club, unless you plan on back cleaning them! Leaving any bolts clipped on Loser's Club would cause your rope to shred over the arete. Also, top roping through the crux with directionals is a little weird. Its best to clip the top three bolts with slings if you plan on top roping.*
content.protection: 6 bolts. I like to clip the even number bolts with  12" draws.
content.location: Look for the only painted bolts on the wall.

content.description: Funky climbing in a shallow corner.  Mostly decent but devious slopers and crimps with an occasional jug.  Crux is pulling into the finishing left-leaning undercling crack.
content.protection: 5 bolts, optional gear (.75 or 1 camalot), lower-off anchors.

content.description: Killer climbing on a steep, clean, blocky wall.  Stem through the first few bolts, hit a couple jugs, then pull the first crux past a bad gaston to a big left-hand edge at the 5th bolt. Cop a quick rest, and fire a long crux to the anchors, finishing with a deadpoint/dyno to the lip. Full on and one of the best routes at LOTL.
content.location: Right side of the Three Amigos wall.

content.description: Slopers, sidepulls and stemming.  Crux is pulling past the 4th bolt on a right hand sloper to a small crimp.  Mostly good edges and pockets after this.
content.location: Far right side of the Three Amigos Wall.

content.description:
A steep and daunting dihedral with superb rock quality and thoughtful movement. Begin in a flaring squeeze chimney and perform a bouldery sequence to gain an excellent rest. Stem, crimp, palm, jam, and grovel your way up the highly physical dihedral, peeking around the left wall to find some useful footholds. After clipping the 6th bolt, traverse right to the arete with delicate crimps and lots of air beneath you. For added fun, do a hard boulder problem up the steep "V" instead of the traverse. Finish on steep, glorious jugs. Go ahead, cut your feet and just hang there. You earned it.

This route will draw from all corners of your climbing toolbox and is well worth the arduous approach. Join the club!
content.protection: 7 bolts, 2 bolt anchor. The first bolt seems high, but is easily clipped from a hands-free knee-bar with your right leg.
content.location: The dihedral to the right of Zacher Cracker and left of Piano Hoist.

content.description: Links Piano Hoist into M.I.A.; significantly harder than Piano Hoist but skips the lower crux on M.I.A.  Clip the first 4 bolts of Piano Hoist, then bust right past three more bolts to the M.I.A. anchors.  The crux comes at the last move with a big deadpoint/dyno to the lip.
content.location: Same start as Piano Hoist; look for the route that splits about 2/3 of the way up.

content.description: Start on a left-leaning hand crack, traverse right, and move up into splitter fingers.  Cool stemming leads to a right-hand jug over the crux bulge.  Worth a lap if you're warming up for Zacher Cracker or Lost and Forgotten.
content.location: Far left side of the Three Amigos Wall, just after the tunnel-through.

content.description:
Wow. This thing is a masterpiece! With the first bolt pre-clipped, step off the lower shelf of rock into a perfect double-arete compression boulder problem. An absolutely perfect (and very technical) sequence leads to a knee-bar clip at the third bolt. Cross through to the fourth bolt, then enter the crux, which is.... hard. Very hard. It is sequential, powerful, off balance compression between bad holds. Expect to log some airtime figuring this one out!

The line was first envisioned and bolted by Nic Sabo, but left as an open project. Once I discovered the path of least resistance took you straight over to the arete, I chopped one bolt, placed another above, and one lower to prevent the inevitable leg breaker fall (ever seen Gaia??). With the relocated bolt and a soft catch, the falls are exciting, but plenty safe. The name comes because after my first day working the route on lead I was in pain for a full week!
content.location: Arete right of Loser's Club. Shares the last bolt with Loser's Club.

content.description: Right leaning flake/fist crack from base of the finger section on Land of the Mossed. Bump fist jams and jugs along, smearing feet below. finish with a delicate topout through loose rock. Good alternative if Land of the Mossed is harder than you thought.
content.protection: gear to 4", two 3's are nice. tie block for anchor.
content.location: right of Land of the Mossed

content.description:
Short, steep, and quality! Bridge up an obtuse dihedral towards an out of reach jug. Follow rails to the third bolt (great jugs and a very airy clip). With a difficult right hand crimp/pinch, crank for a high left hand pinch and a good clipping crimp. After the fourth bolt, throw left to the arete and enjoy an all-jugs finish.

This one's been on my bolting list for quite some time, and turned out to be a very worthy pursuit! Get on it!
content.location: Climb a line of four black bolts left of Piano Hoist (tan bolts)

content.description: Start behind near a large snag and work some delicate moves up the face. Continues up past a bulge to a good stance where the anchors are located. Fun varied climbing and a good warm up for the more difficult routes in the area. Should clean up with more traffic.
content.location: Climbers right of Lost Boys just around the corner. Look for the big dead tree.
